abstract.p: Lawrence Van Gelder reports on exhibit of paintings from Detroit Institute of Arts at Phillips Collection in Washington, a Dario Fo performance at Barnard College, an exhibition at Jewish Museum of on the art and traditions of Morocco and its Jewish life, and a program of discounted tickets for young people called High 5; photos (M)

block.p: They were champions of modern art, Robert Tannahill of Detroit (1893-1967) and Duncan Phillips of Washington (1886-1966). Beginning on Saturday, similarities and differences in their tastes will be visible at the Phillips Collection in Washington in ''Degas to Matisse: Impressionist and Modern Masterworks From the Detroit Institute of Arts.'' The show runs through Jan. 21.

The Nobel Prize-winning dramatist Dario Fo and his wife, the actress Franca Rame, perform at 8 tonight in the Woman of the World Festival at the Minor Latham Playhouse of Barnard College at Broadway and 117th Street in Morningside Heights. Mr. Fo will enact excerpts from his ''Mistero Buffo'' and Ms. Rame will appear in the New York premiere of ''Sex? Thanks, Don't Mind If I Do,'' written by them and their son Jacopo. . . . At 110th Street and Broadway the William Schuman Award Concert, honoring Steve Reich for lifetime achievement by an American composer, will usher in the 2000-2001 season at Miller Theater of Columbia University at 7:30 tonight.

Orientalist paintings by artists like Delacroix. Jewelry and ceremonial objects of silver and gold. Sumptuous textiles. Photographs. Spanning 2,000 years, more than 180 objects that illuminate the art and traditions of Morocco and its Jewish life go on view on Sunday at the Jewish Museum. ''Morocco: Jews and Art in a Muslim Land'' continues through Feb. 11. Besides the visions of outsiders, the show reflects the insider's perspective through objects created by Jews in a culture descended from ancient Berber traditions.

For $5 or less, the doors swing open to hundreds of events, from salsa to opera and ''Oedipus Rex.'' The medium for this magic is High 5, a program that makes the arts affordable for students ages 13 to 18 from New York and New Jersey. Tickets to weekend events are $5 each; tickets to Monday through Thursday performances are two for $5. For $25 covering six tickets, one adult may accompany five students or two adults may accompany four to a High 5 event. Beginning tomorrow, the High 5 fall catalog will be at bookstores, libraries, many Ticketmaster outlets and High 5's offices at 1 East 53rd Street in Manhattan.
